prompt: Choosing the right data for user-facing SLOs (e.g., LCP/INP targets)

options.text: Real User Monitoring (field) at the 75th percentile, segmented by route and device classes
Lab data from a single CI Lighthouse run on fast hardware
Synthetic checks only; users are too noisy
Error log volume per minute

explanation: Field p75 by route/device reflects real user experience and avoids masking regressions in averages.
explanationIncorrect: Lab-only: Misses real devices/networks.
Synthetic-only: Complementary but not representative of users.
Error volume: Reliability signal, not a UX performance SLO.
source: web.dev: Core Web Vitals (field p75); Chrome UX Report; SRE Workbook (SLOs)

prompt: Correlating frontend UX with backend latency

options.text: Propagate W3C Trace Context (traceparent) on fetch/XHR to link frontend spans to backend traces
Use Server-Timing to expose backend phases and trace IDs to the browser
Only log console.time() in the browser; correlation is unnecessary
Rely on opaque CDN cache logs; no need to instrument the app

explanation: Trace propagation: Connects frontend spans to backend traces for end-to-end visibility.
Server-Timing: Surfaces backend phase timings/trace IDs to correlate with UX metrics.
explanationIncorrect: Console timers only: Uncorrelated and incomplete.
CDN logs only: Opaque and cannot tie to user experience.
source: W3C Trace Context; MDN: Server-Timing; OpenTelemetry docs

prompt: Alerting on user-visible errors without paging on noise

options.text: Page when the rate of unhandled exceptions crosses a threshold per release/route and cohort
De-duplicate by error fingerprint and exclude benign aborts (e.g., AbortError)
Alert on every console.error globally
Use rolling windows and require a minimum sample size before paging

explanation: Impact thresholds: Page only for sustained, cohort-specific user impact.
Dedup/filter: Fingerprint errors and drop non-actionable noise like cancellations.
Windows/samples: Stabilize alerts and avoid single-event paging.
explanationIncorrect: Alert on every console.error: Creates alert fatigue and hides real issues.

prompt: Sampling and cost control for telemetry

options.text: Head-sample normal traces (e.g., 5–10%), but keep 100% of error events and selected key transactions
Tail-based sampling in the backend and dynamic upsampling on anomalies
Drop all RUM beacons on slow networks to save cost
Session-based sampling (e.g., 1 in N sessions) to avoid bias toward heavy users

explanation: Head sampling + error passthrough: Reduces volume while preserving critical signals.
Tail sampling: Keeps interesting outliers and anomalies via backend decisions.
Session sampling: Avoids per-event bias and captures user-level context.
explanationIncorrect: Drop slow-network RUM: Discards the most important signals for UX.

options.text: Implement kill switches via remote config; default to a safe state if config fails to load
Couple flags with telemetry (emit variant in events) and allow per-cohort rollbacks
Evaluate flags only at build time to enable tree-shaking
Use flags for authorization decisions so permissions can change instantly

explanation: Kill switches: Rapid mitigation path with fail-safe defaults on config failure.
Telemetry coupling: Variant attribution enables targeted rollbacks and impact analysis.
explanationIncorrect: Evaluate flags: Build-time flags remove runtime control.
Auth via flags: Authorization should not rely on mutable client-side flags.

options.text: Maintain per-service runbooks with SEV classification, contacts, rollback steps, and dashboards/queries
Detect incidents exclusively via Slack user reports
Practice game days and postmortems with actionable follow-ups
Treat SLO breaches as FYI and only act on absolute outages

explanation: Runbooks: Prepared procedures reduce MTTR during incidents.
Game days/postmortems: Practice and learning loops reduce recurrence.
explanationIncorrect: User reports only: Reactive and slow incident detection.
Ignore SLO breaches: Undermines reliability commitments.

options.text: Prefer role/text selectors; wait on UI states or network idleness over fixed sleeps; avoid cross-test data coupling
Insert fixed 5-second sleeps after each navigation
Stub animations and control time to remove nondeterminism
Mock all network calls in E2E so they never hit a backend

explanation: Robust selectors/waits: Target user-visible states and avoid brittle timing.
Deterministic timing: Disable animations and control clocks to reduce nondeterminism.
explanationIncorrect: Fixed sleeps: Brittle and slow.
Mock everything: Stops being end-to-end; keep critical paths real.
source: Cypress/Playwright best practices; Testing Library guidance

options.text: Use Pact (or similar) so the provider verifies consumer expectations in CI
Record once, replay forever (VCR) to lock behaviors
Maintain OpenAPI/JSON Schema and run breaking-change checks in CI
Only rely on manual Swagger review before releases

explanation: CDC in CI: Enforces compatibility by verifying consumer expectations.
Schema checks: Automated diffing flags breaking changes early.
explanationIncorrect: Record/replay only: Brittle data and hides real drift.
Manual review only: Error-prone without enforcement.
source: Pact docs; OpenAPI validation tooling; Martin Fowler on contract testing

options.text: Many fast unit tests, fewer integration tests, a small number of E2E for critical journeys
Snapshot most components and treat snapshots as the safety net
Write an E2E for every UI permutation
Skip tests; rely on monitoring and flags only

explanation: Balanced pyramid optimizes feedback speed and confidence; E2E is reserved for highest-value flows.
explanationIncorrect: Snapshot-heavy: Noisy, weak behavior signal.
All-E2E permutations: High cost and flakiness.
Monitoring-only: Complements tests, does not replace them.
source: Google Testing Blog; Martin Fowler: Test Pyramid

options.text: Use Testing Library queries by role/label and assert visible outcomes over implementation details
Use MSW to stub network at the boundary in integration tests
Prefer snapshotting the entire DOM tree
Query mainly by test IDs to avoid a11y coupling

explanation: Role/label queries: Mimic real user interactions and improve a11y.
MSW boundary stubs: Hermetic yet realistic network behavior.
explanationIncorrect: Full-DOM snapshots: Noisy and brittle.
Test IDs only: Useful sparingly; weaker alignment with user behavior.
source: Testing Library docs; MSW docs; Kent C. Dodds guidance

options.text: Spin ephemeral DBs/containers per suite; seed fixtures; rollback/truncate between tests
Parallelize against a shared staging DB to mimic production
Randomize ports/namespaces; reset global singletons between tests
Depend on wall-clock time; never mock timers

explanation: Isolated environments: Prevent cross-test bleed and nondeterminism.
Namespace/time control: Avoid global collisions and stabilize timing.
explanationIncorrect: Shared staging: Induces test flakiness and interference.
Real-time only: Adds timing noise and flakes.
source: Docker test envs; Playwright/Cypress isolation tips; Jest/Vitest timers

options.text: Gate merges on p75 Web Vitals regressions, per-package coverage floors, change-affected coverage; sample mutation testing
Enforce 100% global coverage for all files
No coverage thresholds; trust the process
Gate merges on Lighthouse score only

explanation: Field vitals + targeted coverage and mutation sampling align quality gates with user impact and code risk.
explanationIncorrect: 100% global coverage: Incentivizes shallow tests.
No thresholds: Insufficient guardrails.
Single-score gate: Easy to game and not diagnostic.
source: Chrome UX field guidance; Stryker mutation testing; pragmatic coverage practices

prompt: Guardrails vs primary metric in an A/B test (checkout)

options.text: Primary: conversion to purchase; Guardrails: error rate, p75 LCP, add-to-cart latency, refund rate
Primary: pageviews; Guardrails: time-on-site
Primary: revenue/user; Guardrails: sample ratio mismatch (SRM)
Primary: conversion; Guardrails: none—guardrails reduce power

explanation: Business KPI as primary plus UX/reliability guardrails prevents harmful 'wins' that degrade experience.
explanationIncorrect: Weak proxies: Pageviews/time-on-site are not business outcomes.
SRM as guardrail: SRM is a health check, not a guardrail metric.
No guardrails: Risks shipping regressions masked by uplift.

prompt: Detecting and responding to sample ratio mismatch (SRM)

options.text: Run a chi-square goodness-of-fit on assignment counts; pause if p < 0.001
Ignore SRM if overall variance looks normal
Common causes include randomization bugs, asymmetric bot filters, and eligibility checks after assignment
Fix by reweighting post-hoc and keep the same run

explanation: Statistical check: Chi-square on assignment counts detects SRM reliably.
Root causes: Pipeline bugs and asymmetric filtering frequently cause SRM.
explanationIncorrect: Ignore SRM: Invalidates inference regardless of variance.
Post-hoc reweight: Cannot repair broken randomization; restart after fixing.
source: Evan Miller: How Not to Run an A/B Test; Booking.com/MExP SRM posts

options.text: Use group-sequential or always-valid methods (alpha-spending, sequential likelihood ratio, Bayesian with stopping rules) to allow interim looks
Peek daily at p<0.05 without correction; ship if significant
Fix by collecting exactly N users and never looking early
Use Bayesian posteriors but still apply frequentist p-value thresholds

explanation: Sequential designs control error while enabling interim decisions and agility.
explanationIncorrect: Uncorrected peeking: Inflates Type I error.
Fixed-N only: Removes flexibility; not required with sequential methods.
Framework mixing: Incoherent decision criteria.
source: Jennison & Turnbull (Group Sequential Methods); Google/Amplitude sequential testing guides

options.text: Use pre-experiment user metrics (e.g., past-week spend/visits) as covariates to reduce variance and required sample size
Winsorize revenue at the 99.9th percentile and call it CUPED
Randomize at the session level to reduce variance for user KPIs
Stratify or block by important covariates during assignment

explanation: Control variates (CUPED): Use pre-experiment covariates to reduce variance without bias.
Stratified randomization: Balance key covariates to improve precision.
explanationIncorrect: Winsorizing: Outlier trimming is not CUPED and does not exploit covariance.
Session-level randomization: Increases variance for user-level outcomes due to within-user correlation.
source: Deng et al. (CUPED); Kohavi et al., Trustworthy Online Controlled Experiments

options.text: Ramp 1%→5%→25%→50%→100% with automatic rollback if guardrails breach
Roll to 100% immediately to maximize learning speed
Use kill switches and per-cohort rollbacks; emit variant in telemetry
Ignore heterogeneity; one global effect is enough for decisions

explanation: Progressive delivery: Limits blast radius and enables safe, staged rollout.
Guardrails/telemetry: Fast rollback and variant attribution for targeted mitigation.
explanationIncorrect: Immediate 100%: High risk of widespread impact.
Ignore heterogeneity: Masks subgroup harm (e.g., slow devices or networks).
source: Progressive delivery best practices; SRE change management
